results.title: Le Carrosse D'or = the Golden Coach
results.brief_description:
This play, a fantasy in the Italian style, takes place at the beginning of the 18th century in a Spanish colony of Latin America ruled by viceroys appointed by the King of Spain. Although filmed in English, this is essentially an Italian film reflecting what Renoir saw as his ‘move towards classicism … of Italy before Verdi and romanticism’. Attention to detail in dress and decor (and Vivaldi’s music), was important to this shift in style. Renoir saw his film not as drama, farce or burlesque but as a ‘sort of irony that I tried to combine with the light-headedness one finds, for example, in Goldini [an 18th century Italian comic dramatist].’ He saw the period and the subject as theatrical so he structured the film like a three act play with the acting ‘a little exaggerated … a confusion of theatre and life’. Renoir diverted Magnani’s ‘ultra-romantic, naturalistic style’ into the mix of spontaneity and classicism central to the commedia dell’arte.

Credits: Producer, Francesco Alliata ; director, Jean Renoir ; writers, Jean Renoir, Jack Kirkland, Renzo Avanzo, Giulio Macchi ; photography, Claude Renoir ; music, Antonio Vivaldi.
Cast: Anna Magnani, Duncan Lamont, Paul Campbell, Riccardo Rioli, Odoardo Spadaro.

results.title: Le Capitan
results.creator_credit: Paul Cadeac, Pierre Caband, Rene Bezard and Andre Hunebelle
results.brief_description:
In 1616 King Louis XIII is only 15 and his kingdom is administered by Regent Marie de Medicis and her favourite, Concini. Concini hopes to use power and influence to overthrow the young king but his plan is violently opposed by the peers of the Kingdom who have their own candidate to the succession, Charles d’Angouleme. As Concini terrorises his opponents, the kingdom is on the verge of a civil war. In order to save his life and his throne, the young king enlists the help of Francois, also known as Le Capitan, the best swashbuckler of the kingdom, and his sidekick, Cogolin.

Credits: Producers, Paul Cadeac, Pierre Caband, Rene Bezard ; director, Andre Hunebelle ; writers, Jean Halain, Pierre Foucaud, Andre Hunebelle ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; music, Jean Marion.
Cast: Pierrette Bruno, Lise Delamare, Annie Anderson, Guy Delorme, Jean Marais.

results.title: Le Capitaine H
results.brief_description: We follow the “Genevilliers”, a petrol barge, along the River Seine from the throbbing harbour to the mellow arches of Paris. Life bounded by the ever-changing banks has its own special kind of freedom. Captain Michael hacke and his family see the river in different weathers, colors and moods. They feel a unique brotherhood with their fellow river dwellers, a chance meeting with relatives is an occasion for celebration. No matter how the life of a bargee may change with time, the river remains a world unto itself. Commentary in English. Photography by Roger Fellous and jean-Jacques Languepin. Music by Jean Wiener.

results.title: Le Caillou
results.brief_description: A documentary about New Caledonia, which shows the nickel plant, and the inroads mining has made on the environment. Traditional forms of agriculture are shown, as well as the traditions of village life. These continue despite the French presence in the territory and the effects of nearly a century of resource exploitation on New Caledonia’s environment. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Le Cadeau
results.brief_description: An animated film in which a little man after many unsuccessful attempts manages to make a trumpet emit the appropriate sound. This film won first prize for animation at the Westdeutsche Kurzfilmtage and first prize at Cork International Film Festival. Animation by Michel Altermatt and Rene Guillaume. No narration, music only.

results.title: Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme = the Would-Be Gentleman
results.brief_description:
Monsieur Jourdain is a vulgar nouveau-riche attempting to buy his way into the uppermost rings of society.

Credits: Director, Roger Coggio ; writers, Roger Coggio, Bernard G. Landry ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Jean Bouchety ; choreography, Claude Bessy.
Cast: Rosy Varte, Roger Coggio, Ludmila Mikael, Michel Galabru, Jean-Pierre Darras, Robert Manuel, Etienne Chicot.

results.title: Le Bossu = the Hunchback
results.brief_description:
Lagardere vows to protect Aurore, the baby daughter of his friend, Philippe de Nevers, who has just been murdered by his cousin Gonzague, who was coveting his fortune. Falsely accused of the murder, Lagardere swears he will seek to avenge his friend and help Aurore recover her fortune and rank in society. This favourite swashbuckling adventure has also been filmed by Andre Hunebelle (1960) and Philippe de Broca (1997).

Credits: Producer, Jason Regina ; director, Jean Delannoy ; writer, Bernard Zimmer ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Georges Auric.
Cast: Paul Bernard, Pierre Blanchar, Yvonne Gaudeau, Jean Marchat, Lucien Nat, Helene Vercors.

results.title: Le Bonheur et la Mort = Happiness and Death
results.brief_description:
In the XIVth century, art is no longer controlled by the church or the kings. The new mecenes are the princes and the patrician class. Under their impulse, art becomes more attentive to the depiction of secular life. Works of art are less gandiose, smaller and destined to a private use as illustrated by the somptuous Livre d’Heures (prayer book) commissioned by Duke Jean de Berry. XIVth century aristocracy is intoxicated by stories of chivalry and the knights of round table. Art depicts in minute details the idyllic life of knight, entirely devoted to hunting, tournament and the pursuit of ‘l’amour courtois’.

Credits: Director, Roland Darbois ; writers, Roger Stephane, Roland Darbois, photography, Roland Dantigny.
Cast: Narrated by Georges Duby.

results.title: Le Bonheur = Happiness
results.brief_description:
Anarchist Philippe Lutcher vows to kill anyone who represents ‘the establishment’. He ends up shooting idolised music-hall singer Clara Stuart in full view of her audience. The singer escapes death and the two get to know each other, eventually falling in love. At the trial, Clara offers to testify in favour of Philippe, but he refuses, determined to become a martyr to his cause.

Credits: Director, Marcel L’Herbier ; photography, Harry Stradling ; music, Billy Colson ; technical collaboration, Jean Dreville.
Cast: Gaby Morlay, Charles Boyer, Paulette Dubost, Michel Simon, Jean Toulout.

results.title: Le Bois des Amants = Lovers' Grove
results.brief_description:
During WWII, Herta von Stauffen travels to Normandy with a fake Ausweiss and a borrowed uniform to be with her husband for Christmas. She is billeted at Madame Parisot’s whose son, Charles, has joined the British army.

Credits: Producer, Ray Ventura ; director, Claude Autant-Lara ; writers, Albert Husson, Rene Hardy, Jacques Remy ; photography, Jacques Natteau ; music, Rene Cloerec ; art direction, Max Douy.
Cast: Laurent Terzieff, Erika Remberg, Francoise Rosay, Horst Franck, Gert Froebe, Francoise Rosay.
